title: Zambia: Assurance On Mine Jobs Timely
text:
Zambia: GBM Says What Happened in Mulobezi Won't Be Entertained By Lubansenshi editorial 
This week's pronouncement by President Edgar Lungu and the Government that mines jobs are safe could not have come at a better time. 
Glencore, Vedanta Resources, China's NFC Africa and CNMC Luanshya Copper Mine all recently threatened to shut down some operations in Zambia because of the harsh business environment. 
This included the slide in copper prices, the free fall of the Kwacha, and the power deficit. 
According to some media reports, over 6,000 jobs would be lost as a result of that move and this information became a source of worry to the miners and the Zambian populace in general. 
Other fears have been that the suspension of production at Glencore's Mopani Mines and at the Chinese-operated CNMC Luanshya Copper Mines in Zambia will depress the country's growth and reduce proceeds from exports and royalties. 
According to experts, the suspension or threats of suspension of some mining operations introduced a downside risk to the Government's revised growth projections. 
The experts say that Zambia's growth, which has averaged more than seven per cent per year over the past decade, is now at risk of falling to the Sub-Saharan Africa median. 
Experts further said the suspension of mine operations would reduce copper output and this would mean that Zambia's fiscal deficit would be likely to widen by another 75-1.00 percentage point of Gross Domestic Product (GDP) because of the reduced tax base. 
The announcement; however, by President Lungu that mines jobs will be safe has come at the right time. 
President Lungu said he had engaged mining companies to prevent massive job losses on the Copperbelt following reports that job cuts are looming due to reduced copper prices on the international market. 
Mining companies have also assured President Lungu in meetings that they are ready to invest heavily to make mines more resilient to low copper prices and subsequently save jobs. 
The assurance shows that President Lungu is concerned and does not want to see mass job losses in the mining sector in the interest of the nation and the economy. 
According to Government information, the mining companies and in particular Mopani Copper Mines have assured President Lungu of huge investments to modernise the mine in Mufulira and Kitwe. 
The investments would be made in the next 18 months and would make the mine more resilient to shocks like low copper prices. 
Other reports have, however, started indicating that Glencore's MCM will retain most of its workers even after copper production is suspended. 
It is believed that Mopani is talking with Government and unions over Glencore's plan to suspend operations and invest to improve efficiency at the mine. 
It is hoped that the move by Government and the mines could help save thousands of jobs. 
Over the next 18 months, Mopani is expected to invest $500 million in expansion projects and a large number of employees are expected to be kept for mine development and care and maintenance. 
This will help Mopani to be efficient and competitive in the global copper market. It will also extend the mine life. 
Mopani is the second largest employer in Zambia after the Government with about 21 000 direct and contract workers. 
Secretary to the Treasury Fredson Yamba, recently also assured that Government would continue to promote investments by providing a predictable, consistent and stable environment to protect and secure the many jobs created by the sector. 
Additionally, the operationalisation of the revised mining law to streamline issuance of mining licences, the establishment of a tribunal and promotion of local content will enhance development in the sector. 
According to Mr Yamba, the Mining sector is earmarked for growth because the copper output is projected to increase from 741,916 metric tonnes this year to 916,767 metric tonnes in 2018 largely on the account of the improved output at Kansanshi Mine in Solwezi due to the new smelter. 
Production at Konkola Copper Mines is also projected to increase because of the Konkola Deep Mining Project which is due to start operating soon. 
The development of Kalumbila and Chambeshi West Ore would also spur growth in the mining sector. 
Mr Yamba said the mining and quarrying sector is set to benefit from the mineral diversification by enhancing production of minerals such as nickel, gold, iron, manganese and uranium. 
From what has been indicated above, it is clear that Government is determined to promote growth in the mining sector and promote development thereby preventing job cuts in the sector. Zambia
